tools.name: add_label_to_email
tools.description: Adds and/or removes specified Gmail labels for a message; ensure `message_id` and all `label_ids` are valid (use 'listLabels' for custom label IDs).

add_label_ids.description:
Label IDs to add. For custom labels, obtain IDs via 'listLabels'. System labels (e.g., 'INBOX', 'SPAM', 'STARRED', 'IMPORTANT') can be used, but immutable system labels like 'DRAFT' and 'SENT' cannot be added or removed.
Examples:
  "STARRED"
  "IMPORTANT"
  "Label_123"

message_id.description:
Immutable ID of the message to modify (e.g., from 'fetchEmails' or 'fetchMessagesByThreadId').
Example: "17f1b2b9c1b2a3d4"

remove_label_ids.description:
Label IDs to remove. For custom labels, obtain IDs via 'listLabels'. System labels can be used, but immutable system labels like 'DRAFT' and 'SENT' cannot be added or removed via messages.modify.
Examples:
  "UNREAD"
  "Label_456"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: batch_delete_messages
tools.description: Tool to permanently delete multiple Gmail messages in bulk. Use when you need to efficiently remove large numbers of emails (e.g., retention enforcement, mailbox hygiene).

ids.description:
List of message IDs to delete. Obtain IDs via list or fetch actions.
Example: ["18c5f5d1a2b3c4d5","18c5f5d1a2b3c4d6"]

userId.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: batch_modify_messages
tools.description: Modify labels on multiple Gmail messages in one efficient API call. Supports up to 1,000 messages per request for bulk operations like archiving, marking as read/unread, or applying custom labels.

addLabelIds.description:
List of label IDs to add to the messages. Common label IDs: INBOX, STARRED, IMPORTANT, SENT, DRAFT, SPAM, TRASH, UNREAD. Use GMAIL_LIST_LABELS to get custom label IDs. Leave empty to skip adding labels.
Examples:
  ["INBOX","STARRED"]
  ["Label_123","Label_456"]
  ["IMPORTANT"]

messageIds.description:
List of message IDs to modify. Maximum 1,000 message IDs per request. Get message IDs from GMAIL_FETCH_EMAILS or GMAIL_LIST_THREADS actions.
Examples:
  ["18c5f5d1a2b3c4d5","18c5f5d1a2b3c4d6"]
  ["msg_id_1","msg_id_2","msg_id_3"]

removeLabelIds.description:
List of label IDs to remove from the messages. Common use cases: Remove 'UNREAD' to mark as read, remove 'INBOX' to archive, remove 'SPAM' to unmark spam. Leave empty to skip removing labels.
Examples:
  ["UNREAD"]
  ["INBOX","UNREAD"]
  ["SPAM"]

userId.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: create_email_draft
tools.description: Creates a Gmail email draft, requiring at least one of recipient_email, cc, or bcc must be provided. Atleast one of subject or body must be provided. Supports To/Cc/Bcc, subject, plain/HTML body (ensure `is_html=True` for HTML), attachments, and threading. When creating a draft reply to an existing thread (thread_id provided), leave subject empty to stay in the same thread; setting a subject will create a NEW thread instead.

attachment.description: File to attach to the email.

bcc.description:
Blind Carbon Copy (BCC) recipients' email addresses. Atleast one of cc, bcc, or recipient_email must be provided.
Example: ["bcc.recipient@example.com"]

body.description:
Email body content (plain text or HTML); `is_html` must be True if HTML. Either subject or body must be provided. Examples: "Hello Team, Please find the attached report for your review. Best regards, Your Name" "

Meeting Confirmation

This email confirms our meeting scheduled for next Tuesday.

"

cc.description:
Carbon Copy (CC) recipients' email addresses. Atleast one of cc, bcc, or recipient_email must be provided.
Example: ["cc.recipient1@example.com","cc.recipient2@example.com"]

extra_recipients.description:
Additional 'To' recipients' email addresses (not Cc or Bcc). Should only be used if recipient_email is also provided.
Example: ["jane.doe@example.com","another.recipient@example.com"]

is_html.description:
Set to True if `body` is HTML, otherwise the action may fail.
Examples:
  true
  false

recipient_email.description:
Primary recipient's email address. Required if cc and bcc is not provided, else can be optional. Use extra_recipients if you want to send to multiple recipients.
Example: "john.doe@example.com"

subject.description:
Email subject line. Either subject or body must be provided. When creating a draft reply to an existing thread (thread_id provided), leave this empty to stay in the same thread. Setting a subject will create a NEW thread instead.
Examples:
  "Project Update Q3"
  "Meeting Reminder"

thread_id.description:
ID of an existing Gmail thread to reply to; omit for new thread.
Example: "17f45ec49a9c3f1b"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: create_label
tools.description: Creates a new label with a unique name in the specified user's Gmail account.

background_color.description:
Background color for the label. Must be selected from Gmail's predefined color palette of over 100 colors (not arbitrary hex values). If setting a color, both background_color and text_color must be provided. See the official Color field documentation for the full palette: https://developers.google.com/workspace/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#Color
Examples:
  "#4a86e8"
  "#43d692"

label_list_visibility.description:
Controls how the label is displayed in the label list in the Gmail sidebar.
Examples:
  "labelShow"
  "labelShowIfUnread"
  "labelHide"

label_name.description:
The name for the new label. Must be unique within the account, non-blank, maximum length 225 characters, cannot contain ',', '/', or '.' (period), not only whitespace, and must not be a reserved system label (e.g., INBOX, SENT, DRAFT, SPAM, TRASH, ALL_MAIL, CATEGORY_*).
Examples:
  "Work"
  "Important Documents"
  "Receipts 2024"

message_list_visibility.description:
Controls how messages with this label are displayed in the message list.
Examples:
  "show"
  "hide"

text_color.description:
Text color for the label. Must be selected from Gmail's predefined color palette of over 100 colors (not arbitrary hex values). If setting a color, both text_color and background_color must be provided. See the official Color field documentation for the full palette: https://developers.google.com/workspace/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#Color
Examples:
  "#000000"
  "#ffffff"
  "#aa8831"

user_id.description:
The email address of the user in whose account the label will be created.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: delete_draft
tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific Gmail draft using its ID; ensure the draft exists and the user has necessary permissions for the given `user_id`.

draft_id.description:
Immutable ID of the draft to delete, typically obtained when the draft was created.
Example: "r-8388446164079304564"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user; 'me' is recommended.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: delete_message
tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific email message by its ID from a Gmail mailbox; for `user_id`, use 'me' for the authenticated user or an email address to which the authenticated user has delegated access.

message_id.description:
Identifier of the email message to delete.
Examples:
  "185120e4428ba8cf"
  "17a872b77b9e7a3b"

user_id.description:
User's email address. The special value 'me' refers to the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: fetch_emails
tools.description: Fetches a list of email messages from a Gmail account, supporting filtering, pagination, and optional full content retrieval.

ids_only.description:
If true, only returns message IDs from the list API without fetching individual message details. Fastest option for getting just message IDs and thread IDs.
Examples:
  true
  false

include_payload.description:
Set to true to include full message payload (headers, body, attachments); false for metadata only.
Examples:
  true
  false

include_spam_trash.description:
Set to true to include messages from 'SPAM' and 'TRASH'.
Examples:
  true
  false

label_ids.description: Filter by label IDs; only messages with all specified labels are returned. Common IDs: 'INBOX', 'SPAM', 'TRASH', 'UNREAD', 'STARRED', 'IMPORTANT', 'CATEGORY_PRIMARY' (alias 'CATEGORY_PERSONAL'), 'CATEGORY_SOCIAL', 'CATEGORY_PROMOTIONS', 'CATEGORY_UPDATES', 'CATEGORY_FORUMS'. Use 'listLabels' action for custom IDs.

max_results.description:
Maximum number of messages to retrieve per page.
Examples:
  "10"
  "100"
  "500"

page_token.description: Token for retrieving a specific page, obtained from a previous response's `nextPageToken`. Omit for the first page.

query.description:
Gmail advanced search query (e.g., 'from:user subject:meeting'). Supports operators like 'from:', 'to:', 'subject:', 'label:', 'has:attachment', 'is:unread', 'after:YYYY/MM/DD', 'before:YYYY/MM/DD', AND/OR/NOT. Use quotes for exact phrases. Omit for no query filter.
Examples:
  "from:john@example.com is:unread"
  "subject:meeting has:attachment"
  "after:2024/01/01 before:2024/02/01"
  "is:important OR is:starred"
  "label:work -label:spam"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

verbose.description:
If false, uses optimized concurrent metadata fetching for faster performance (~75% improvement). If true, uses standard detailed message fetching. When false, only essential fields (subject, sender, recipient, time, labels) are guaranteed.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: fetch_message_by_message_id
tools.description: Fetches a specific email message by its ID, provided the `message_id` exists and is accessible to the authenticated `user_id`.

format.description:
Format for message content: 'minimal' (ID/labels), 'full' (complete data), 'raw' (base64url string), 'metadata' (ID/labels/headers).
Examples:
  "minimal"
  "full"
  "raw"
  "metadata"

message_id.description:
Unique ID of the email message to retrieve, obtainable from actions like 'List Messages'.
Example: "xsdfe3264vrfw"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "user@example.com"
  "me"

tools.name: fetch_message_by_thread_id
tools.description: Retrieves messages from a Gmail thread using its `thread_id`, where the thread must be accessible by the specified `user_id`.

page_token.description:
Opaque page token for fetching a specific page of messages if results are paginated.
Example: "CiAKGhIKJdealEffectivelyPageToken"

thread_id.description:
Unique ID of the thread, obtainable from actions like 'listThreads' or 'fetchEmails'.
Example: "xsdfe3264vrfw"

user_id.description:
The email address of the user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: forward_message
tools.description: Forward an existing Gmail message to specified recipients, preserving original body and attachments.

additional_text.description:
Optional additional text to include before the forwarded content.
Example: "Please see the forwarded message below."

message_id.description:
ID of the message to forward, obtainable from actions like 'List Messages'.
Example: "17f45ec49a9c3f1b"

recipient_email.description:
Email address to forward the message to.
Example: "john.doe@example.com"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: get_attachment
tools.description: Retrieves a specific attachment by ID from a message in a user's Gmail mailbox, requiring valid message and attachment IDs.

attachment_id.description:
ID of the attachment to retrieve. Make sure that attachment_id is passed and is valid, not a placeholder or NULL.
Example: "A_PART0.1_18exampleAttachmentId7f9"

file_name.description:
Desired filename for the downloaded attachment. Make sure that file_name is passed
Examples:
  "invoice.pdf"
  "report.docx"

message_id.description:
Immutable ID of the message containing the attachment. Make sure that message_id is passed and is valid, not a placeholder or NULL.
Example: "18exampleMessageId7f9"

user_id.description:
User's email address ('me' for authenticated user).
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: get_contacts
tools.description: Fetches contacts (connections) for the authenticated Google account, allowing selection of specific data fields and pagination.

include_other_contacts.description: Include 'Other Contacts' (interacted with but not explicitly saved) in addition to regular contacts; if true, fetches from both endpoints and merges results.

page_token.description: Token to retrieve a specific page of results, obtained from 'nextPageToken' in a previous response.

person_fields.description:
Comma-separated person fields to retrieve for each contact (e.g., 'names,emailAddresses').
Examples:
  "addresses"
  "ageRanges"
  "biographies"
  "birthdays"
  "coverPhotos"
  "emailAddresses"
  "events"
  "genders"
  "imClients"
  "interests"
  "locales"
  "memberships"
  "metadata"
  "names"
  "nicknames"
  "occupations"
  "organizations"
  "phoneNumbers"
  "photos"
  "relations"
  "residences"
  "sipAddresses"
  "skills"
  "urls"
  "userDefined"

resource_name.description: Identifier for the person resource whose connections are listed; use 'people/me' for the authenticated user.

tools.name: get_people
tools.description: Retrieves either a specific person's details (using `resource_name`) or lists 'Other Contacts' (if `other_contacts` is true), with `person_fields` specifying the data to return.

other_contacts.description: If true, retrieves 'Other Contacts' (people interacted with but not explicitly saved), ignoring `resource_name` and enabling pagination/sync. If false, retrieves information for the single person specified by `resource_name`.

page_size.description: The number of 'Other Contacts' to return per page. Applicable only when `other_contacts` is true.

page_token.description: An opaque token from a previous response to retrieve the next page of 'Other Contacts' results. Applicable only when `other_contacts` is true and paginating.

person_fields.description:
A comma-separated field mask to restrict which fields on the person (or persons) are returned. Consult the Google People API documentation for a comprehensive list of valid fields.
Examples:
  "names,emailAddresses"
  "emailAddresses,names,birthdays,genders"
  "addresses,phoneNumbers,metadata"

resource_name.description:
Resource name identifying the person for whom to retrieve information (like the authenticated user or a specific contact). Used only when `other_contacts` is false.
Examples:
  "people/me"
  "people/c12345678901234567890"
  "people/102345678901234567890"

sync_token.description: A token from a previous 'Other Contacts' list call to retrieve only changes since the last sync; leave empty for an initial full sync. Applicable only when `other_contacts` is true.

tools.name: get_profile
tools.description: Retrieves key Gmail profile information (email address, message/thread totals, history ID) for a user.

user_id.description:
The email address of the Gmail user whose profile is to be retrieved, or the special value 'me' to indicate the currently authenticated user.
Examples:
  "user@example.com"
  "me"

tools.name: list_drafts
tools.description: Retrieves a paginated list of email drafts from a user's Gmail account. Use verbose=true to get full draft details including subject, body, sender, and timestamp.

max_results.description:
Maximum number of drafts to return per page.
Examples:
  10
  100
  500

page_token.description:
Token from a previous response to retrieve a specific page of drafts.
Example: "CiaKJDhWSE5UURE9PSIsImMiOiJhYmMxMjMifQ=="

user_id.description:
User's mailbox ID; use 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

verbose.description:
If true, fetches full draft details including subject, sender, recipient, body, and timestamp. If false, returns only draft IDs (faster).
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: list_history
tools.description: Tool to list Gmail mailbox change history since a known startHistoryId. Use when performing incremental mailbox syncs to fetch only new changes.

history_types.description:
Filter by specific history types. Allowed values: messageAdded, messageDeleted, labelAdded, labelRemoved.
Example: ["messageAdded","labelRemoved"]

label_id.description:
Only return history records involving messages with this label ID.
Example: "INBOX"

max_results.description:
Maximum number of history records to return. Default is 100; max is 500.
Examples:
  100
  500

page_token.description:
Token to retrieve a specific page of results.
Example: "ABCDEF123456"

start_history_id.description:
Required. Returns history records after this ID. If the ID is invalid or too old, the API returns 404. Perform a full sync in that case.
Example: "1234567890"

user_id.description:
The user's email address. Use 'me' to specify the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: list_labels
tools.description: Retrieves a list of all system and user-created labels for the specified Gmail account.

user_id.description:
Identifies the Gmail account (owner's email or 'me' for authenticated user) for which labels will be listed.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: list_threads
tools.description: Retrieves a list of email threads from a Gmail account, identified by `user_id` (email address or 'me'), supporting filtering and pagination.

max_results.description:
Maximum number of threads to return.
Examples:
  "10"
  "50"
  "100"

page_token.description:
Token from a previous response to retrieve a specific page of results; omit for the first page.
Example: "abcPageToken123"

query.description:
Filter for threads, using Gmail search query syntax (e.g., 'from:user@example.com is:unread').
Examples:
  "is:unread"
  "from:john.doe@example.com"
  "subject:important"

user_id.description:
The user's email address or 'me' to specify the authenticated Gmail account.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

verbose.description:
If false, returns threads with basic fields (id, snippet, historyId). If true, returns threads with complete message details including headers, body, attachments, and metadata for each message in the thread.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: modify_thread_labels
tools.description: Adds or removes specified existing label IDs from a Gmail thread, affecting all its messages; ensure the thread ID is valid.

add_label_ids.description:
List of label IDs to add to the thread; these labels must exist.
Examples:
  "STARRED"
  "INBOX"

remove_label_ids.description:
List of label IDs to remove from the thread; these labels must exist.
Examples:
  "IMPORTANT"
  "CATEGORY_UPDATES"

thread_id.description:
Immutable ID of the thread to modify.
Example: "18ea7715b619f09c"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "user@example.com"
  "me"

tools.name: move_to_trash
tools.description: Moves an existing, non-deleted email message to the trash for the specified user.

message_id.description:
Identifier of the email message to move to trash.
Example: "1875f42779f726f2"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "user@example.com"
  "me"

tools.name: patch_label
tools.description: Patches the specified label.

backgroundColor.description:
The background color of the label, represented as a hex string. Must be one of Gmail's predefined colors from the color palette. See: https://developers.google.com/workspace/gmail/api/guides/labels#color_palette
Examples:
  "#ffffff"
  "#f3f3f3"
  "#efefef"
  "#cccccc"

textColor.description:
The text color of the label, represented as a hex string. Must be one of Gmail's predefined colors from the color palette. See: https://developers.google.com/workspace/gmail/api/guides/labels#color_palette
Examples:
  "#000000"
  "#434343"
  "#666666"
  "#ffffff"

color.description: The color to assign to the label. Color is only available for labels that have their `type` set to `user`.

id.description:
The ID of the label to update.
Example: "LABEL_123"

labelListVisibility.description:
The visibility of the label in the label list in the Gmail web interface.
Examples:
  "labelShow"
  "labelShowIfUnread"
  "labelHide"

messageListVisibility.description:
The visibility of messages with this label in the message list in the Gmail web interface.
Examples:
  "show"
  "hide"

name.description:
The display name of the label.
Example: "My Updated Label"

userId.description:
The user's email address. The special value `me` can be used to indicate the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: remove_label
tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific, existing user-created Gmail label by its ID for a user; cannot delete system labels.

label_id.description:
ID of the user-created label to be permanently deleted; must exist and not be a system label.
Examples:
  "Label_123"
  "Label_xyz789"

user_id.description:
User's email address or 'me' for the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: reply_to_thread
tools.description: Sends a reply within a specific Gmail thread using the original thread's subject, requiring a valid `thread_id` and at least one of recipient_email, cc, or bcc must be provided. Supports attachments via the `attachment` parameter with valid `s3key`, `mimetype`, and `name`.

attachment.description: File to attach to the reply. Just Provide file path here

bcc.description:
Blind Carbon Copy (BCC) recipients' email addresses. Atleast one of cc, bcc, or recipient_email must be provided.
Example: ["bcc.recipient@example.com"]

cc.description:
Carbon Copy (CC) recipients' email addresses. Atleast one of cc, bcc, or recipient_email must be provided.
Example: ["cc.recipient1@example.com","cc.recipient2@example.com"]

extra_recipients.description:
Additional 'To' recipients' email addresses (not Cc or Bcc). Should only be used if recipient_email is also provided.
Example: ["jane.doe@example.com","another.person@example.com"]

is_html.description:
Indicates if `message_body` is HTML; if True, body must be valid HTML, if False, body should not contain HTML tags.
Examples:
  true
  false

message_body.description:
Content of the reply message, either plain text or HTML.
Example: "Dear Sir, Nice talking to you. Yours respectfully, John"

recipient_email.description:
Primary recipient's email address. Required if cc and bcc is not provided, else can be optional. Use extra_recipients if you want to send to multiple recipients.
Example: "john@doe.com"

thread_id.description:
Identifier of the Gmail thread for the reply.
Example: "x53r3vdevff"

user_id.description:
Identifier for the user sending the reply; 'me' refers to the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: search_people
tools.description: Searches contacts by matching the query against names, nicknames, emails, phone numbers, and organizations, optionally including 'Other Contacts'.

other_contacts.description: When True, searches both saved contacts and 'Other Contacts' (people you've interacted with but not explicitly saved). Note: This restricts person_fields to only 'emailAddresses', 'names', 'phoneNumbers'. When False, searches only saved contacts but allows all person_fields including 'organizations', 'addresses', etc.

pageSize.description: Maximum results to return; values >30 are capped to 30 by the API.

person_fields.description:
Comma-separated fields to return (e.g., 'names,emailAddresses'). When 'other_contacts' is true, only 'emailAddresses', 'names', 'phoneNumbers' are allowed. For full field access including 'organizations', set 'other_contacts' to false.
Examples:
  "addresses"
  "ageRanges"
  "biographies"
  "birthdays"
  "coverPhotos"
  "emailAddresses"
  "events"
  "genders"
  "imClients"
  "interests"
  "locales"
  "memberships"
  "metadata"
  "names"
  "nicknames"
  "occupations"
  "organizations"
  "phoneNumbers"
  "photos"
  "relations"
  "residences"
  "sipAddresses"
  "skills"
  "urls"
  "userDefined"

query.description: Matches contact names, nicknames, email addresses, phone numbers, and organization fields.

tools.name: send_draft
tools.description: Sends the specified, existing draft to the recipients in the To, Cc, and Bcc headers.

draft_id.description:
The ID of the draft to send. Make sure that the draft ID is valid and not a placeholder. You can use GMAIL_LIST_DRAFTS or GMAIL_CREATE_EMAIL_DRAFT to get the draft ID, if you don't have it.
Example: "r-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"

user_id.description:
The user's email address. The special value `me` can be used to indicate the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "me"
  "user@example.com"

tools.name: send_email
tools.description: Sends an email via Gmail API using the authenticated user's Google profile display name. At least one of recipient_email, cc, or bcc must be provided. Atleast one of subject or body must be provided. Requires `is_html=True` if the body contains HTML and valid `s3key`, `mimetype`, `name` for any attachment.

attachment.description: File to attach; ensure `s3key`, `mimetype`, and `name` are set if provided. Omit or set to null for no attachment.

bcc.description:
Blind Carbon Copy (BCC) recipients' email addresses. Atleast one of cc, bcc, or recipient_email must be provided.
Example: ["auditor@example.com"]

body.description:
Email content (plain text or HTML). Either subject or body must be provided for the email to be sent. If HTML, `is_html` must be `True`. Examples: "Hello team, let's discuss the project updates tomorrow." "

Welcome!

Thank you for signing up.

" ""

cc.description:
Carbon Copy (CC) recipients' email addresses. Atleast one of cc, bcc, or recipient_email must be provided.
Example: ["manager@example.com","teamlead@example.com"]

extra_recipients.description:
Additional 'To' recipients' email addresses (not Cc or Bcc). Should only be used if recipient_email is also provided.
Example: ["jane.doe@example.com","support@example.com"]

is_html.description: Set to `True` if the email body contains HTML tags.

recipient_email.description:
Primary recipient's email address. Required if cc and bcc is not provided, else can be optional. Use extra_recipients if you want to send to multiple recipients.
Example: "john@doe.com"

subject.description:
Subject line of the email. Either subject or body must be provided for the email to be sent.
Examples:
  "Project Update Meeting"
  "Your Weekly Newsletter"

user_id.description:
User's email address; the literal 'me' refers to the authenticated user.
Examples:
  "user@example.com"
  "me"

tools.name: create_linked_in_post
tools.description: Creates a new post on LinkedIn for the authenticated user or an organization they manage; ensure the user has necessary permissions if posting for an organization.

author.description:
The URN of the LinkedIn member or organization creating the post. Use the GET_USER_INFO action to retrieve the 'author_id' (URN) for the authenticated user. For an organization, the URN will be in the format 'urn:li:organization:{id}'.
Examples:
  "urn:li:person:123456789"
  "urn:li:organization:987654321"

commentary.description:
The main text content of the post. This field supports plain text and @-mentions (e.g., @[LinkedIn Member](urn:li:person:xxxx)). Maximum length: 3000 characters.
Examples:
  "Excited to share our new product update!"
  "Check out this insightful article: [link]"

feedDistribution.description: Specifies how the post is distributed on the LinkedIn feed. 'MAIN_FEED' distributes to the main feed, 'NONE' creates Direct Sponsored Content and requires adContext.dscAdAccount (adContext parameter not exposed in this action).

targetEntities.description: A list of entities to target with this post. Each entity should be a dictionary. This is often used for targeted distribution, e.g., to specific groups or GeoLocations. For GeoLocations, provide a dictionary like: `{'geoLocations': [{'geo': 'urn:li:geo:103644278'}]}`. Refer to LinkedIn documentation for specific URN formats.

thirdPartyDistributionChannels.description: A list of third-party channels where the post should be distributed, e.g., Twitter. Refer to LinkedIn documentation for supported channels.

distribution.description: Specifies distribution rules for the post, including feed distribution and targeting.

isReshareDisabledByAuthor.description: Set to true to prevent others from resharing this post.

lifecycleState.description:
The state of the post. Use 'PUBLISHED' to post directly, 'DRAFT' to save as a draft, or 'PUBLISH_REQUESTED' if the post requires review before publishing.
Examples:
  "PUBLISHED"
  "DRAFT"
  "PUBLISH_REQUESTED"

visibility.description: Controls who can see the post. 'PUBLIC' makes it visible to everyone, 'CONNECTIONS' to connections only, 'LOGGED_IN' to signed-in LinkedIn members, and 'CONTAINER' for specific group/event posts.

tools.name: delete_linked_in_post
tools.description: Deletes a specific LinkedIn post (share) by its unique `share_id`, which must correspond to an existing share.

share_id.description:
Unique identifier of the LinkedIn share (post) to be deleted.
Example: "7245341016004718592"

tools.name: get_company_info
tools.description: Retrieves organizations where the authenticated user has specific roles (ACLs), to determine their management or content posting capabilities for LinkedIn company pages.

count.description:
The number of organization ACLs to return per page.
Examples:
  "10"
  "50"
  "100"

role.description:
The specific role to filter organization ACLs by.
Examples:
  "ADMINISTRATOR"
  "DIRECT_SPONSORED_CONTENT_POSTER"

start.description:
The starting index for pagination, representing the number of initial ACLs to skip.
Examples:
  "0"
  "10"
  "20"

state.description:
The approval state of the role to filter by.
Examples:
  "APPROVED"
  "REQUESTED"

tools.name: get_my_info
tools.description: Fetches the authenticated LinkedIn user's profile, notably including the 'author_id' required for attributing content such as posts or articles.
